Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves

Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves is an upcoming American fantasy adventure film directed by Jonathan Goldstein and John Francis Daley, written by Goldstein and Daley, and starring Chris Pine, Michelle Rodriguez, and Hugh Grant. The film is a spin-off of the popular Dungeons & Dragons franchise and is set to be released in 2023.

#Plot

The film follows a group of thieves, led by Edgin (Chris Pine), who are tasked with stealing a powerful artifact from a wealthy collector. However, their plan goes awry when they are double-crossed by one of their own members, and they are forced to flee for their lives. As they navigate the treacherous world of thieves and nobles, they must also confront their own personal demons and learn to trust each other if they hope to survive.

The film also stars Sophia Lillis as a young half-elf thief named Doric, who joins Edgin's crew and helps them on their mission. Other cast members include Jake Mintz as a charismatic thief named Simon, and Regé-Jean Page as a mysterious figure known only as the Sage.

#Cast

* Chris Pine as Edgin
* Michelle Rodriguez as Holga
* Hugh Grant as Forge Fitzwilliam
* Sophia Lillis as Doric
* Jake Mintz as Simon
* Regé-Jean Page as the Sage
* Justice Smith as Simon's brother
* Daisy Head as a young noblewoman
* Chloe Coleman as a street urchin

#Production

##Development and casting

The film was first announced in 2020, with Chris Pine and Michelle Rodriguez attached to star. Jonathan Goldstein and John Francis Daley were brought on board to write and direct the film, which is set to be a spin-off of the popular Dungeons & Dragons franchise. The film's budget is estimated to be around $150 million, making it one of the most expensive films of the year.

##Writing

The screenplay for the film was written by Jonathan Goldstein and John Francis Daley, who are known for their work on films such as Game Night and Vacation. The script is said to be a mix of action, adventure, and comedy, with a focus on the characters and their relationships with each other.

##Filming and visual effects

Principal photography for the film began in September 2021 and wrapped in February 2022. The film was shot on location in the United States and the United Kingdom, with a mix of practical and visual effects being used to bring the world of Dungeons & Dragons to life.

#Music

The film's score is being composed by Danny Elfman, who is known for his work on films such as Spider-Man: No Way Home and The Nightmare Before Christmas. The soundtrack is set to be released in conjunction with the film's release.

#Release

##Theatrical

Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves is set to be released in theaters on March 31, 2023. The film will be released in the United States and several other countries, with a wide release expected.

##Home media

The film is set to be released on home media in conjunction with its theatrical release. The DVD and Blu-ray versions of the film will include bonus features such as deleted scenes and behind-the-scenes footage.

#Marketing

##Promotion

The film's marketing campaign is being led by Paramount Pictures and has included a mix of trailers, posters, and social media promotions. The film's trailer was released in December 2022 and has been viewed millions of times on YouTube.

##Tie-in literature and merchandise

The film's success has led to the creation of tie-in literature and merchandise, including a novelization of the film and a line of action figures.

#Reception

##Box office

The film is set to be a commercial success, with estimates suggesting that it will gross over $500 million worldwide.

##Critical response

The film has received positive reviews from critics, with many praising its action sequences, visuals, and performances. The film has a rating of 82% on Rotten Tomatoes, with many critics praising its unique take on the Dungeons & Dragons franchise.

##Accolades

The film has been nominated for several awards, including the MTV Movie Awards and the People's Choice Awards. The film's score has also been nominated for several awards, including the Critics' Choice Movie Awards.

#Future

##Possible sequel

A sequel to the film is currently in development, with Chris Pine and Michelle Rodriguez set to reprise their roles. The sequel is expected to be released in 2025.

##Spin-off television series

A spin-off television series is also in development, with Paramount Pictures and Amazon Studios set to produce. The series is expected to follow a group of characters from the film and is expected to be released in 2024.

#Notes

Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves is a unique take on the popular Dungeons & Dragons franchise, blending action, adventure, and comedy in a way that is sure to appeal to fans of the franchise and newcomers alike.

**2021–22 Premier League**

The 2021–22 Premier League was the 30th season of the Premier League, the top English professional league for association football clubs, since its establishment in 1992. The season began on 13 August 2021 and ended on 22 May 2022.

**The race for first place**

The 2021–22 Premier League season was highly competitive, with several teams vying for the title. Manchester City, who had won the league in the previous two seasons, were looking to make it three in a row. However, they faced stiff competition from Liverpool, who were looking to win their first league title in 30 years. Chelsea, who had won the Champions League in the previous season, were also in the mix, as were Manchester United and Arsenal.

The season was marked by a series of twists and turns, with several teams rising to the top of the table only to be overtaken by others. In the end, it came down to the final day of the season, when Manchester City and Liverpool were separated by just one point. Manchester City ultimately won the title, finishing with 93 points from 38 matches.

**Newcastle takeover**

One of the major stories of the 2021–22 Premier League season was the takeover of Newcastle United by a Saudi-led consortium. The takeover was completed in October 2021, and it marked a new era for the club. The takeover was worth £305 million, and it was seen as a major coup for the club.

The takeover was not without controversy, however. There were concerns about the human rights record of the Saudi Arabian government, and the club's new owners faced criticism for their links to the government. Despite these concerns, the takeover was seen as a major boost for the club, and it marked a new era of investment and ambition.

**COVID-19 outbreaks force postponements**

The 2021–22 Premier League season was also marked by a series of COVID-19 outbreaks, which forced several matches to be postponed. The outbreaks were caused by the spread of the Omicron variant, which was highly contagious and caused widespread disruption.

Several matches were postponed, including a match between Liverpool and Leeds United, which was postponed due to a COVID-19 outbreak at Leeds. The outbreak forced several members of the Leeds squad to isolate, and the match was eventually rescheduled for a later date.

**Abramovich sanctions**

The 2021–22 Premier League season was also marked by the sanctions imposed on Chelsea owner Roman Abramovich. The sanctions were imposed by the UK government in response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and they banned Abramovich from owning a British company.

The sanctions had a major impact on Chelsea, who were forced to sell their stadium and other assets. The club's future was uncertain, and it was unclear whether they would be able to survive without Abramovich's backing.

**Final day climax**

The 2021–22 Premier League season ended in a thrilling climax, with several teams battling for the title. Manchester City and Liverpool were separated by just one point, and it came down to the final day of the season to see who would win the title.

Manchester City beat Aston Villa 3-2 in their final match of the season, while Liverpool drew 3-3 with Southampton. Manchester City won the title by a single point, finishing with 93 points from 38 matches.

**Title**

The 2021–22 Premier League title was won by Manchester City, who finished with 93 points from 38 matches. The title was their third in four seasons, and it marked a major achievement for the club.

The 2021–22 Premier League season also saw several teams relegated to the Championship. The teams that were relegated were Norwich City, Watford, and Burnley.

The 2021–22 Premier League season also saw several teams qualify for European competition. The teams that qualified for the Champions League were Manchester City, Liverpool, Chelsea, and Tottenham Hotspur.

article:
Matty Healy

Matty Healy is a British musician, singer, songwriter, and record producer. He is best known as the lead vocalist and guitarist of the British pop rock band The 1975. Healy has been active in the music industry since the early 2000s and has gained a significant following worldwide for his unique voice, thought-provoking lyrics, and energetic live performances.

Early Life

Matthew Peter Healy was born on April 19, 1989, in London, England. His father, Tim Healy, is an English actor, and his mother, Denise Healy, is a former competition swimmer. Healy's parents were married in 1988 and divorced in 1993. He has two younger sisters, Jessica and Ellie.

Career

### 2002–2011: Beginnings, and early years of the 1975

Matty Healy's music career began in 2002, when he formed a band called The 1975 with his friend Adam Hann. The band's early sound was heavily influenced by 1980s pop and rock music. Healy attended Wilmslow High School in Cheshire, where he met his future bandmates Adam Hann, Ross MacDonald, and George Daniel. The band's name, The 1975, was inspired by a Jack Kerouac reference to the year 1975 as a turning point in American history.

### 2012–2014: Rise to fame

The 1975 released their debut EP, "Facedown," in 2012. The EP received positive reviews from critics and helped the band gain a following in the UK indie music scene. In 2013, the band released their debut single, "The City," which gained significant airplay on BBC Radio 1. The 1975's debut album, I Like It When You Sleep, for You Are So Beautiful yet So Unaware of It, was released in 2016.

### 2015–2017: Breakthrough

The 1975's breakthrough came in 2016 with the release of their sophomore album, I Like It When You Sleep, for You Are So Beautiful yet So Unaware of It. The album was a critical and commercial success, peaking at number one on the UK Albums Chart and earning the band a Grammy nomination for Best Rock Album. The album's lead single, "The Sound," was a hit, reaching number two on the UK Singles Chart.

### 2018–2021: Critical acclaim

The 1975's third album, A Brief Inquiry into Online Relationships, was released in 2018. The album received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising Healy's thought-provoking lyrics and the band's experimental sound. The album's lead single, "Give Yourself a Try," was a hit, reaching number 21 on the UK Singles Chart.

### 2022–present: Further success

The 1975's fourth album, Notes on a Conditional Form, was released in 2020. The album was a critical and commercial success, peaking at number one on the UK Albums Chart. The album's lead single, "If You're Too Shy (Let Me Know)," was a hit, reaching number 11 on the UK Singles Chart. The 1975's fifth album, Being Funny in a Foreign Language, was released in 2022.

Artistry

### Influences

Matty Healy's music is influenced by a wide range of artists, including The Beatles, David Bowie, and Radiohead. He has also cited influences from 1980s pop and rock music, including Prince, Michael Jackson, and Whitney Houston.

### Voice

Healy's voice is known for its unique tone and range. He has a distinctive, soaring quality that has been praised by critics and fans alike. Healy has also been praised for his vocal range, which spans over three octaves.

### Songwriting

Healy is a skilled songwriter, known for his thought-provoking and often humorous lyrics. He has written songs on a wide range of topics, including love, relationships, and social issues. Healy's songwriting style is often described as introspective and personal.

### Performance style

Healy is known for his energetic live performances, which often feature elaborate lighting and visual effects. He has a reputation for being a charismatic and engaging performer, and has been praised for his ability to connect with audiences.

Legacy

### Healywave

The term "Healywave" was coined by fans to describe the emotional and introspective quality of Healy's music. The term has been used to describe the band's music, as well as Healy's solo work.

article:
The 2022 French legislative election was held on 12 and 19 June 2022 to elect the 577 members of the National Assembly of France. The election was the first to be held under the new Constitution of 2022, which had been adopted in 2021.

# Background

The 2022 French legislative election was the result of a combination of factors, including the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, the economic crisis, and the growing sense of discontent among the French population. The election was also marked by a significant shift in the political landscape, with the rise of new parties and the decline of traditional ones.

The election was also notable for the fact that it was the first to be held under the new Constitution of 2022, which had been adopted in 2021. The new Constitution introduced significant changes to the electoral system, including the reduction of the number of deputies from 577 to 550, and the introduction of a new system of proportional representation.

# Electoral system

The 2022 French legislative election was held using a mixed-member proportional representation system. Under this system, each of the 577 deputies was elected using a combination of two votes: a constituency vote and a list vote.

In the constituency vote, voters chose their preferred candidate from among the list of candidates standing in their constituency. The candidate with the most votes in each constituency was elected as a deputy.

In the list vote, voters chose from among the lists of candidates presented by the different parties. The number of deputies elected from each list was determined by the proportion of votes received by each list.

# Dates

The 2022 French legislative election was held on two dates: 12 June 2022 for the first round, and 19 June 2022 for the second round.

## First round

The first round of the election was held on 12 June 2022. In this round, voters chose from among the list of candidates standing in their constituency, as well as from among the lists of candidates presented by the different parties.

The results of the first round were as follows:

* Voter turnout: 65.6%
* Number of registered voters: 47,574,321
* Number of valid votes: 31,151,621

## Second round

The second round of the election was held on 19 June 2022. In this round, voters chose from among the list of candidates standing in their constituency, as well as from among the lists of candidates presented by the different parties.

The results of the second round were as follows:

* Voter turnout: 74.9%
* Number of registered voters: 47,574,321
* Number of valid votes: 35,601,319

## National results

The national results of the election were as follows:

* Number of deputies elected: 577
* Number of parties represented: 9
* Number of seats held by the largest party: 250

## Results by constituency

The results of the election by constituency were as follows:

* Number of constituencies: 577
* Number of deputies elected: 577
* Number of seats held by the largest party: 250

## Electorate

The electorate for the 2022 French legislative election was as follows:

* Number of registered voters: 47,574,321
* Voter turnout: 65.6% (first round), 74.9% (second round)

# Aftermath

## Formation of parliamentary groups

Following the election, the deputies elected formed two main parliamentary groups: the Ensemble (Together) group, which was led by Emmanuel Macron, and the Rassemblement National (National Rally) group, which was led by Marine Le Pen.

## Vote of no confidence

On 21 June 2022, the Ensemble group presented a motion of no confidence against the government of Élisabeth Borne. The motion was adopted by 270 votes to 248, and the government was forced to resign.

article:
**Salman Rushdie**

Salman Rushdie is a British-Indian novelist, essayist, and broadcaster of Indian descent. He has been a prominent figure in contemporary literature, known for his unique blend of magical realism, historical fiction, and satire. Rushdie has written over 20 novels, essays, and non-fiction works, and has been translated into more than 40 languages.

**Early Life and Education**

Salman Rushdie was born on June 19, 1947, in Mumbai (then Bombay), India, to Anis Ahmed Rushdie, a merchant, and Negin Bhatt, a homemaker. His family was of mixed Parsi and Muslim ancestry. Rushdie's early life was marked by a love for literature and storytelling, which was encouraged by his mother. He attended the Cathedral and John Connon School in Mumbai and later moved to the UK with his family in 1960.

Rushdie studied history at King's College, Cambridge, where he was exposed to the works of E.M. Forster, Virginia Woolf, and other notable authors. He graduated in 1968 and moved to London, where he began his career as a writer.

**Career**

**Copywriter**

Before becoming a full-time writer, Rushdie worked as a copywriter in advertising agencies in London and New York. He wrote for several prominent brands, including Ogilvy & Mather and DDB Worldwide. Rushdie's experience as a copywriter helped him develop his writing skills and his ability to think creatively.

**Literary Works**

#### **Early Works and Literary Breakthrough, 1975–1987**

Rushdie's first novel, **Grimus**, was published in 1975, but it was his second novel, **Midnight's Children**, that brought him widespread recognition. Published in 1981, **Midnight's Children** is a magical realist tale that explores the experiences of a group of children born at the stroke of midnight on August 15, 1947, the day of India's independence from British rule. The novel won the Booker Prize in 1981 and cemented Rushdie's reputation as a rising literary star.

**The Satanic Verses and Haroun and the Sea of Stories, 1988–1990**

In 1988, Rushdie published **The Satanic Verses**, a novel that explores the experiences of two Indian immigrants in London and their encounters with the supernatural. The book was a critical and commercial success, but it also sparked widespread controversy due to its depiction of the Prophet Muhammad. In response, Ayatollah Khomeini issued a fatwa calling for Rushdie's death.

Rushdie's next novel, **Haroun and the Sea of Stories**, was published in 1990. The book is a fantastical tale that explores the power of storytelling and the importance of imagination.

#### **Further Works, 1990s–2000s**

In the 1990s, Rushdie published several novels, including **The Moor's Last Sigh** and **The Ground Beneath Her Feet**. These novels continued to explore themes of identity, culture, and politics, and were widely praised for their literary merit.

**Later Works, Novels, and Essays, 2015–2024**

In recent years, Rushdie has published several essays, including **Two Years Eight Months and Twenty-Eight Nights** and **The Golden House**. He has also continued to write novels, including **The Lycan** and **The Stranger's Child**.

**Critical Reception**

Rushdie's work has been widely praised for its literary merit, its exploration of complex themes, and its innovative use of language. He has been compared to authors such as Gabriel García Márquez and Toni Morrison, and has been recognized as one of the most important writers of his generation.

**Academic and Other Activities**

Rushdie has taught creative writing at several universities, including Yale and Harvard. He has also given numerous lectures and talks on literature and politics, and has been a vocal advocate for freedom of speech and human rights.

**Film and Television**

Rushdie's work has been adapted into several films and television shows, including **The Satanic Verses** and **Midnight's Children**. He has also appeared in several documentaries and television programs, including **The NewsHour with Jim Lehrer** and **Charlie Rose**.

**The Satanic Verses and the Fatwā**

**Failed Assassination Attempt (1989)**

On February 14, 1989, Rushdie was attacked by a mob of Islamist extremists in London. He was stabbed in the neck and suffered serious injuries, but survived the attack.

**Hezbollah's Comments (2006)**

In 2006, Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah called for Rushdie's execution, saying that he was a "martyr" and a "symbol of the West's attack on Islam."

**International Guerillas (1990)**

In 1990, Rushdie received a threatening letter from a group of Islamic extremists, who claimed to be affiliated with the Iranian government. The letter warned Rushdie that he would be killed if he did not retract his comments about the Prophet Muhammad.

The Eras Tour

The Eras Tour is a concert tour by American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift, in support of her tenth studio album, Midnights (2022). The tour was announced on November 1, 2022, and has been one of the most highly anticipated and talked-about tours of the year.

Background

The Eras Tour is divided into two distinct periods: the first leg, which took place from March 2023 to March 2024, and the second leg, which began in May 2024.

US Dates
The first leg of the tour kicked off on March 17, 2023, in Glendale, Arizona, and made stops in major cities across the United States, including Los Angeles, Houston, and Chicago. The tour visited a total of 32 cities in the US, with the final show taking place on March 24, 2024, in Tampa, Florida.

International Dates
The tour's international leg began on May 10, 2024, in Tokyo, Japan, and will visit cities in Asia, Latin America, and Europe. The tour will make stops in major cities such as Seoul, Sydney, Rio de Janeiro, and London, among others.

Ticket Sales

US and Canada
Tickets for the tour went on sale on November 4, 2022, and were met with high demand, with many shows selling out quickly. The average ticket price for the US and Canada legs was around $150, with some shows reaching prices as high as $1,000.

The tour features a custom-built stage that is designed to resemble a miniature replica of a highway. The stage is surrounded by a massive LED screen that displays visuals and graphics throughout the show. The lighting design is also custom-made and features a range of colors and patterns that are synchronized with the music and performance.

The tour features a mix of new and old songs, with Swift performing hits from her entire discography, including "Love Story," "Shake It Off," and "Blank Space." The show also features a range of musical performances, including a full band, backup dancers, and a string section.

Swift's fashion choices for the tour have been highly publicized, with the singer-songwriter debuting a range of new outfits and styles throughout the show. The tour features a mix of high-fashion and streetwear-inspired looks, with Swift often changing costumes multiple times throughout the show.

The tour has broken venue records in many cities, including Los Angeles, Houston, and Chicago. The tour's highest-grossing show to date is the Los Angeles show, which grossed over $10 million in ticket sales.

2022 Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly Election

The 2022 Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly election was the 15th Vidhan Sabha election in the Indian state of Himachal Pradesh. It was held on November 12, 2022, and the results were announced on December 8, 2022. The election saw a significant turnout of voters, with the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) winning a majority of seats, ending the Indian National Congress's (INC) 40-year rule in the state.

# Background

## Bypolls and defections

In the run-up to the election, the Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly witnessed several bypolls and defections. The bypolls were held in 2022, with the BJP winning two seats and the INC winning one. The defections saw several INC MLAs join the BJP, further strengthening the latter's position in the state.

# Schedule

The election schedule was announced by the Election Commission of India (ECI) on October 12, 2022. The election was held in a single phase on November 12, 2022, with the counting of votes taking place on December 8, 2022.

# Election statistics

The election saw a total of 17,35,131 eligible voters, with 8,72,698 male and 8,62,433 female voters. The total number of voters who cast their votes was 59,95,661, with an average voter turnout of 61.51%. The highest voter turnout was recorded in the Sirmaur district, with 71.04% of voters exercising their franchise.

# Parties and alliances

## National Democratic Alliance

The National Democratic Alliance (NDA) was an alliance of the BJP and its smaller partners, including the Himachal Lokhit Party (HLP) and the Himachal Janhit Congress (HJC). The alliance won a total of 44 seats, with the BJP winning 38 seats and the HLP winning 3 seats and the HJC winning 3 seats.

## United Progressive Alliance

The United Progressive Alliance (UPA) was an alliance of the INC and its smaller partners, including the Himachal Vikas Congress (HVC). The alliance won a total of 21 seats, with the INC winning 21 seats.

## Aam Aadmi Party

The Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) was a major party contesting in the election. The party won 0 seats, but polled 2,40,032 votes, which was 4.21% of the total votes polled.

## Left Front

The Left Front was an alliance of the Communist Party of India (Marxist) (CPI(M)), the Communist Party of India (CPI), and the Revolutionary Socialist Party (RSP). The alliance won 0 seats, but polled 46,446 votes, which was 0.08% of the total votes polled.

## Others

The other parties contesting in the election included the Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP), the Janta Dal (United) (JD(U)), the Samajwadi Party (SP), and the Swabhimani Paksha (SWP). The BSP won 0 seats, the JD(U) won 0 seats, the SP won 0 seats, and the SWP won 0 seats.

# Candidates

A total of 412 candidates contested in the election, with the highest number of candidates contesting from the Sirmaur district, with 49 candidates.

# Campaigns

## Aam Aadmi Party

article:
**2023 Liga Departamental del Perú**

The 2023 Liga Departamental del Perú was the 96th season of the top-level football league in Peru. The season began on April 7, 2023, and concluded on November 29, 2023. A total of 24 teams competed in the tournament, divided into two zones: Zona Costa and Zona Ande.

**Zona Costa**

The teams in the Zona Costa were divided into four groups of five teams each, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the second stage.

### Group A

* **Alianza Universidad**
* **Alfonso Ugarte**
* **César Vallejo**
* **Sport Huancayo**
* **UTC Cajamarquilla**

### Group B

* **Juan Aurich**
* **Unión Minas**
* **Carlos A. Mannucci**
* **Sport Boys**
* **Atlético Grau**

### Group C

* **Real Sociedad**
* **Unión Comercio**
* **Sport Loreto**

### Group D

* **U. César Vallejo**
* **Cienciano**
* **Alianza Atlético**
* **FBC Melgar**
* **Coopsol**

#### Tiebreaker

* Alianza Universidad 1, UTC Cajamarquilla 1 (6-5 Pen.)
* Sport Huancayo 2, César Vallejo 1
* Juan Aurich 1, Sport Boys 1 (4-3 Pen.)
* Carlos A. Mannucci 3, Atlético Grau 2
* Universitario 3, Sport Loreto 1
* Real Sociedad 2, Unión Comercio 1
* U. César Vallejo 2, FBC Melgar 1

**Zona Ande**

The teams in the Zona Ande were divided into two groups of four teams each, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the second stage.

* Universitario 2, UTC Cajamarquilla 1
* Real Sociedad 1, Defensor La Bocana 1 (5-6 Pen.)
* FBC Melgar 3, César Vallejo 2

**Liguilla**

The quarterfinal winners advanced to the Liguilla, where they were joined by the top four teams from the Zona Costa and the top two teams from the Zona Ande.

### Tiebreaker

* Sport Huancayo 1, Universitario 1 (5-4 Pen.)
* FBC Melgar 2, Real Sociedad 1

**Semifinals**

* Sport Huancayo 2, FBC Melgar 1
* Universitario 3, Sport Loreto 1

**Final**

**2022 United States House of Representatives elections in New York**

The 2022 United States House of Representatives elections in New York were held on November 8, 2022, to elect the 27 members of the state's delegation to the 118th United States Congress. The elections were held concurrently with the 2022 United States Senate election in New York and other federal and state elections.

**2020-22 redistricting controversy**

The 2022 elections took place after the 2020 United States Census, which led to a redrawing of congressional district boundaries. The redistricting process was marred by controversy and lawsuits, with many arguing that the new maps were gerrymandered to favor the Republican Party.

**Overview**

A total of 27 seats were up for election in New York, with 22 Democrats and 5 Republicans seeking re-election. The Democratic Party won a majority of the seats, retaining 16 seats and losing 6 seats to the Republican Party.

article:
**Vladimir Putin**

Vladimir Putin is a Russian politician who has been serving as the President of Russia since 2012. Prior to his presidency, he served as the Prime Minister of Russia from 1999 to 2000 and again from 2008 to 2012. He has also been the leader of the United Russia party, which has been the dominant party in Russian politics since 2003.

**Early life**

Vladimir Putin was born on October 7, 1952, in Leningrad, Russian SFSR, Soviet Union (now Saint Petersburg, Russia). His father, Vladimir Spiridonovich Putin, was a conscript in the Soviet Navy, and his mother, Maria Shelomova, was a factory worker. Putin's family lived in a communal apartment in the city's Kirovsky District. He has one younger brother, Viktor.

Putin's early education took place at a local school, where he excelled in sports, particularly judo and sambo. He attended the Saint Petersburg State University, where he studied law and graduated with a degree in international law in 1975.

**Education**

Putin's education continued at the KGB's Red Banner Institute, where he studied foreign intelligence and graduated with a degree in foreign intelligence in 1985. He then worked as a foreign intelligence officer for the KGB, serving in East Germany and later in the Soviet Union.

**KGB career**

Putin's KGB career spanned over a decade, during which he worked in various roles, including as a foreign intelligence officer and a counterintelligence officer. He was stationed in East Germany, where he was involved in the monitoring of Soviet dissidents and the recruitment of East German informants.

In the late 1980s, Putin returned to the Soviet Union and worked in the KGB's Leningrad branch, where he was involved in the monitoring of Russian dissidents and the recruitment of informants. He was also involved in the KGB's efforts to suppress the growing democratic movement in the Soviet Union.

**Political career**

### 1990–1996: Saint Petersburg administration

In 1990, Putin returned to Leningrad and joined the city's administration as an advisor to the city's mayor, Anatoly Sobchak. He was responsible for coordinating the city's economic development and was involved in the privatization of state-owned enterprises.

### 1996–1999: Early Moscow career

In 1996, Putin was appointed as the head of the Federal Security Service (FSB), the successor to the KGB. He was responsible for overseeing the FSB's operations and was involved in the agency's efforts to suppress the growing Chechen separatist movement.

### 1999: First premiership

In August 1999, Putin was appointed as the Prime Minister of Russia by President Boris Yeltsin. He was tasked with forming a new government and was responsible for overseeing the country's economic and social policies.

### 1999–2000: Acting presidency

In December 1999, Yeltsin resigned as President of Russia, and Putin became the acting President of Russia. He was responsible for overseeing the country's transition to a new government and was involved in the drafting of a new constitution.

### 2000–2004: First presidential term

In 2000, Putin was elected as the President of Russia and was re-elected in 2004. During his first term, he implemented a number of policies aimed at modernizing the country's economy and improving its international standing.

### 2004–2008: Second presidential term

In 2004, Putin was re-elected as President of Russia and was re-elected in 2008. During his second term, he implemented a number of policies aimed at improving the country's economic and social development.

### 2008–2012: Second premiership

In 2008, Putin was appointed as the Prime Minister of Russia by President Dmitry Medvedev. He was responsible for overseeing the country's economic and social policies and was involved in the drafting of a new economic development strategy.

### 2012–2018: Third presidential term

In 2012, Putin was re-elected as President of Russia and was re-elected in 2018. During his third term, he implemented a number of policies aimed at improving the country's economic and social development.

#### Annexation of Crimea

In 2014, Putin annexed Crimea from Ukraine, citing the region's historical and cultural ties to Russia. The annexation was widely condemned by the international community, and Russia was subjected to economic sanctions.

#### Intervention in Syria

In 2015, Putin intervened in the Syrian Civil War, supporting the government of Bashar al-Assad. The intervention was widely criticized by the international community, and Russia was subjected to economic sanctions.

#### Russia's interference in the 2016 US election

In 2016, Russia was accused of interfering in the US presidential election, with hackers targeting the Democratic National Committee and other organizations. Putin denied any involvement in the interference.

### 2018–2024: Fourth presidential term

In 2018, Putin was re-elected as President of Russia and was re-elected in 2024. During his fourth term, he implemented a number of policies aimed at improving the country's economic and social development.

#### COVID-19 pandemic

In 2020, Putin implemented a number of policies aimed at mitigating the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the country's economy and healthcare system.

#### Constitutional referendum and amendments

In 2020, Putin oversaw a constitutional referendum that amended the country's constitution to include a number of changes aimed at increasing the president's powers and reducing the authority of the parliament.

#### Iran trade deal

In 2020, Putin oversaw the signing of a trade deal with Iran, which aimed to increase trade between the two countries and reduce their dependence on the US dollar.

#### 2021–2022 Russo-Ukrainian crisis

In 2021, tensions between Russia and Ukraine escalated, with Putin accusing Ukraine of firing on Russian-backed separatists in the Donbass region. The crisis led to a number of diplomatic efforts to de-escalate tensions, but ultimately resulted in a full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022.

#### Full-scale invasion of Ukraine (2022–present)

In 2022, Putin launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine, citing the country's historical and cultural ties to Russia. The invasion was widely condemned by the international community, and Russia was subjected to economic sanctions.

#### ICC arrest warrant

In 2022, the International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for Putin, citing his alleged involvement in war crimes during the invasion of Ukraine.

#### 2023 Wagner rebellion

In 2023, a rebellion broke out among Wagner Group mercenaries in Russia, who were reportedly unhappy with the government's handling of the conflict in Ukraine. The rebellion was ultimately put down by Russian security forces.

**2024–present: Fifth presidential term**

In 2024, Putin was re-elected as President of Russia and was inaugurated for his fifth term. During his fifth term, he is expected to continue implementing policies aimed at improving the country's economic and social development.

**Domestic policies**

### Economic, industrial, and energy policies

Putin has implemented a number of policies aimed at modernizing the country's economy and improving its international standing. These include the development of the country's energy sector, the implementation of a number of infrastructure projects, and the promotion of the country's exports.

### Environmental policy

Putin has implemented a number of policies aimed at mitigating the impact of the country's economic development on the environment. These include the development of green technologies, the implementation of a number of environmental protection measures, and the promotion of sustainable development.

### Religious policy

Putin has implemented a number of policies aimed at promoting the country's traditional values and promoting the role of the Orthodox Church in the country. These include the development of the country's religious infrastructure, the promotion of religious education, and the encouragement of interfaith dialogue.

### Military development

Putin has implemented a number of policies aimed at modernizing the country's military and improving its international standing. These include the development of the country's defense industry, the implementation of a number of military modernization programs, and the promotion of the country's military exports.

### Human rights policy

Putin has implemented a number of policies aimed at promoting human rights in the country. These include the development of the country's human rights infrastructure, the promotion of human rights education, and the encouragement of international cooperation on human rights issues.

### The media

Putin has implemented a number of policies aimed at regulating the country's media. These include the development of the country's media infrastructure, the promotion of independent media, and the encouragement of media pluralism.

### Promoting conservatism

Putin has implemented a number of policies aimed at promoting conservatism in the country. These include the promotion of traditional values, the encouragement of family values, and the promotion of a strong national identity.

### International sporting events

Putin has implemented a number of policies aimed at promoting the country's international sporting profile. These include the hosting of international sporting events, the development of the country's sports infrastructure, and the promotion of the country's sports exports.

**Foreign policy**

### Asia

Putin has implemented a number of policies aimed at improving the country's relations with countries in Asia. These include the development of the country's trade and economic ties with countries in the region, the promotion of the country's energy exports, and the encouragement of regional cooperation.

### Post-Soviet states

Putin has implemented a number of policies aimed at improving the country's relations with post-Soviet states. These include the development of the country's trade and economic ties with countries in the region, the promotion of the country's energy exports, and the encouragement of regional cooperation.

**2022 Luzon Earthquake**

The 2022 Luzon earthquake was a significant seismic event that occurred on April 23, 2022, in the Philippines. The earthquake had a magnitude of 7.0 on the Richter scale and struck the northern part of the island of Luzon, causing widespread damage and loss of life.

**Characteristics**

The earthquake occurred at 5:37 PM Philippine Standard Time (PST) and was centered in the province of Abra, with an epicenter located at 17.62°N 120.71°E. The earthquake had a focal depth of approximately 15 kilometers (9.3 miles) and a moment magnitude of 7.0. The earthquake's rupture area was estimated to be around 100 kilometers (62 miles) long.

**Aftershocks**

In the aftermath of the earthquake, several aftershocks were reported, with the largest one having a magnitude of 6.1. The aftershocks continued for several days, causing additional damage and disruption to daily life. The Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology (PHIVOLCS) reported that the earthquake and its aftershocks were caused by movement along a left-lateral strike-slip fault.

**Intensity**

The earthquake's intensity was felt across northern Luzon, with the provinces of Abra, Ilocos Sur, and Metro Manila reporting the most severe shaking. The earthquake's intensity was measured using the Modified Mercalli Intensity (MMI) scale, with the following readings reported:

**The Boys (TV series)**

The Boys is an American superhero television series based on the comic book series of the same name by Garth Ennis and Darick Robertson. The show is set in a world where superheroes, known as "supes," have become corrupt and are controlled by a powerful corporation called Vought International. The series premiered on Amazon Prime Video on July 26, 2019, and has received widespread critical acclaim for its dark and subversive take on the superhero genre.

**Premise**

The Boys follows a group of vigilantes known as "The Boys" as they take on the corrupt superhero team known as "The Seven," who are controlled by Vought International. The Seven, led by the charismatic and sadistic Homelander, are a team of powerful superheroes who use their abilities for personal gain and to further the interests of their corporate sponsors. The Boys, led by Billy Butcher, a British vigilante with a personal vendetta against The Seven, seek to take down The Seven and expose the truth about their corrupt activities.

The Boys is a show that is deeply concerned with politics and power. The show's creators have said that they were inspired by a number of real-world events and issues, including the rise of fascist and nationalist movements around the world.

The Boys has received widespread critical acclaim for its dark and subversive take on the superhero genre. The show has been praised for its complex characters, its thought-provoking themes, and its willingness to push the boundaries of what is acceptable on television.

Proclamation of Accession of Charles III

The Proclamation of Accession of Charles III was a formal declaration issued on 9 September 2022, announcing the accession of Charles, Prince of Wales, to the British throne following the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II. The proclamation was made in the United Kingdom and various Commonwealth realms, marking the beginning of a new era in the history of the British monarchy.

United Kingdom

The text of the proclamation was read aloud by the Lord Chancellor, Lord True, at a special ceremony held at St. James's Palace in London. The proclamation declared Charles to be the new monarch, and it stated that he had been proclaimed King across the United Kingdom.

Wales

In Wales, the proclamation was read aloud by the First Minister, Mark Drakeford, at a ceremony held at Cardiff Castle. The proclamation was also displayed on a large screen in the city centre, and it was shared on social media using the hashtag #LlaisCymru (Voice of Wales).

Northern Ireland

In Northern Ireland, the proclamation was read aloud by the First Minister, Paul Givan, at a ceremony held at Parliament Buildings in Stormont. The proclamation was also displayed on a large screen in the city centre, and it was shared on social media using the hashtag #NewDecadeNewBeginnings.

"WHEREAS Charles, Prince of Wales, has been proclaimed King of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, and of His other Realms and Territories, and of the Dominion of Canada;

article:
**2022 UEFA Champions League Final**

The 2022 UEFA Champions League Final was the final match of the 2021–22 UEFA Champions League, the 67th season of Europe's premier club football tournament organised by the Union of European Football Associations (UEFA). The match was played on May 28, 2022, at the Stade de France in Saint-Denis, France, between Real Madrid and Liverpool to determine the champions of the 2021–22 UEFA Champions League.

**Background**

The UEFA Champions League is an annual club football competition organised by the Union of European Football Associations (UEFA), one of the most prestigious and widely viewed sporting events in the world. The competition brings together the top-division champions of every UEFA member association, as well as a number of other teams that have been selected through a qualification process. The competition is contested by 32 teams, with the winners advancing to the knockout stage and competing in a series of matches to determine the champion.

The 2022 UEFA Champions League Final was the 67th edition of the competition, and the 27th to be held under the current format. The match was played between Real Madrid, who were seeking to win their 14th European Cup title, and Liverpool, who were seeking to win their seventh European Cup title.

**Previous finals**

The UEFA Champions League Final has been contested by several teams over the years, with Real Madrid being the most successful team in the competition's history. They have won the competition a record 13 times, including a record three consecutive titles from 1956 to 1958. Liverpool have also been successful in the competition, winning the title six times, including five times in the 1970s and 1980s.

Some notable previous finals include:

* 1966 UEFA Champions League Final: Real Madrid 2, Partizan Belgrade 1
* 1981 UEFA Champions League Final: Liverpool 1, Real Madrid 0
* 2005 UEFA Champions League Final: Liverpool 3, AC Milan 3 (Liverpool won 3-2 in a penalty shootout)

**Venue**

The 2022 UEFA Champions League Final was played at the Stade de France in Saint-Denis, France. The Stade de France is a football stadium located in the northern suburbs of Paris, and it has a seating capacity of over 81,000. The stadium was opened in 1998 and has hosted several high-profile football matches, including the 1998 FIFA World Cup Final and the 2006 UEFA Champions League Final.

**Host selection**

The host city for the 2022 UEFA Champions League Final was selected by UEFA in 2019. The Stade de France was chosen as the host venue due to its size and its ability to host large-scale events. The selection of the host city and venue was made through a bidding process, with several cities and venues competing for the right to host the final.

**Route to the final**

Real Madrid and Liverpool qualified for the final by winning their respective semifinal matches. Real Madrid defeated Chelsea 5-4 in a penalty shootout after the match ended 1-1 after extra time, while Liverpool defeated Villarreal 3-2 in a penalty shootout after the match ended 3-3 after extra time.

**Pre-match**

The 2022 UEFA Champions League Final was preceded by a number of events and activities. The match was played on a Saturday evening, and it was broadcast live on television around the world. The match was also attended by a large crowd of fans, who were seated in the stands and cheered on their teams.

**Identity**

The match was played between two teams with rich histories and identities. Real Madrid is one of the most successful and recognizable football clubs in the world, with a legacy of success and a global fan base. Liverpool is also a highly successful and recognizable club, with a rich history and a strong sense of identity and community.

**Officials**

The match was refereed by Clément Turpin, a French referee who has officiated several high-profile matches in the past. The assistant referees were Cyril Gringore and Frédéric Haquette, both of whom are also French officials.

**Opening ceremony**

The match was preceded by an opening ceremony, which featured a number of performances and activities. The ceremony was attended by a large crowd of fans and dignitaries, and it was broadcast live on television around the world.

**Issues entering stadium and match delay**

There were several issues related to the entry of fans into the stadium and the delay of the match. The Stade de France was overcrowded, and there were reports of fans being unable to enter the stadium due to crowd control measures. article:
**European Integration**

European integration is the process of increasing economic, social, and political cooperation among European countries, with the ultimate goal of creating a unified, cohesive, and prosperous region. The concept of integration has evolved over time, with various theories and frameworks shaping the development of European integration.

**History**

The history of European integration can be divided into several phases, each characterized by significant developments and milestones.

### Proto-integration period

The proto-integration period, which spanned from the mid-19th century to the early 20th century, saw the emergence of international organizations and agreements aimed at promoting economic cooperation and reducing trade barriers among European countries. Examples include the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) and the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC), which laid the groundwork for future integration efforts.

### First phase: explaining integration, 1960s onwards

The first phase of European integration, which began in the 1960s, focused on explaining the concept of integration and its benefits. This phase saw the establishment of the European Economic Community (EEC), which aimed to create a common market among its member states. The EEC's success was followed by the creation of the European Monetary System (EMS), which introduced a single currency, the European Currency Unit (ECU).

### Second phase: analyzing governance, 1980s onwards

The second phase of European integration, which started in the 1980s, shifted the focus to analyzing governance and the role of institutions in promoting integration. This phase saw the introduction of the Single European Act (SEA), which aimed to create a single market among EEC member states. The SEA's success was followed by the creation of the European Union (EU) in 1993, which replaced the EEC and introduced a new set of institutions and decision-making processes.

### Third phase: constructing the EU, 1990s onwards

The third phase of European integration, which began in the 1990s, focused on constructing the EU as a cohesive and unified entity. This phase saw the introduction of the Schengen Agreement, which aimed to create a borderless area among EU member states. The Schengen Agreement was followed by the creation of the Eurozone, which introduced a single currency, the Euro, among participating member states.

**Citizens' organisations calling for further integration**

Several citizens' organizations have emerged in recent years, calling for further integration among European countries. These organizations, such as the European Movement and the European Citizens' Initiative, aim to promote greater cooperation and unity among EU member states.

**Overlap of membership in various agreements**

The overlap of membership in various agreements is a significant aspect of European integration. Many EU member states are also members of other regional organizations, such as the Council of Europe and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE).

### Common membership of member states of the European Union

The EU has a common membership policy, which allows member states to participate in various agreements and organizations. This policy has facilitated greater cooperation and coordination among EU member states.

### Most integrated countries

The most integrated countries in Europe are those that have adopted the Euro and participate in the Schengen Area. These countries, such as Germany, France, and the Netherlands, have achieved a high level of economic and social integration.

**Geographic scope**

The geographic scope of European integration is broad, encompassing various regions and countries in Europe.

### Beyond geographic Europe

The concept of European integration extends beyond geographic Europe, with many countries in the Mediterranean region and beyond participating in various regional organizations and agreements.

### Limited to regions within geographic Europe

However, European integration is also limited to regions within geographic Europe, with many countries in Eastern Europe, Central Europe, and the Balkans participating in various regional organizations and agreements.

### Nordic countries

The Nordic countries, including Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden, are highly integrated and have achieved a high level of economic and social cooperation.

### Baltic Sea region

The Baltic Sea region, which includes countries such as Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, is also highly integrated and has achieved a high level of economic and social cooperation.

### Nordic-Baltic Eight

The Nordic-Baltic Eight, a regional organization that includes Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Iceland, Latvia, Lithuania, Norway, and Sweden, aims to promote greater cooperation and unity among its member states.

### Low Countries region (Benelux)

The Low Countries region, which includes countries such as Belgium, the Netherlands, and Luxembourg, is highly integrated and has achieved a high level of economic and social cooperation.

### Black Sea region

The Black Sea region, which includes countries such as Bulgaria, Greece, Romania, and Turkey, is also highly integrated and has achieved a high level of economic and social cooperation.

### United Kingdom and Ireland

The United Kingdom and Ireland are also highly integrated and have achieved a high level of economic and social cooperation.

### Central Europe

Central Europe, which includes countries such as Germany, Austria, and the Czech Republic, is highly integrated and has achieved a high level of economic and social cooperation.

### Eastern Europe

Eastern Europe, which includes countries such as Poland, Hungary, and Slovakia, is also highly integrated and has achieved a high level of economic and social cooperation.

### Danube region

The Danube region, which includes countries such as Austria, Bulgaria, Croatia, Hungary, Romania, and Serbia, is highly integrated and has achieved a high level of economic and social cooperation.

### Balkans

The Balkans, which includes countries such as Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, Macedonia, and Montenegro, are also highly integrated and have achieved a high level of economic and social cooperation.

**Council of Europe**

The Council of Europe is a regional organization that aims to promote greater cooperation and unity among its member states. The Council has a wide range of activities, including human rights, democracy, and education.

**European Political Community**

The European Political Community is a regional organization that aims to promote greater cooperation and unity among its member states. The Community has a wide range of activities, including foreign policy, defense, and economic cooperation.

**Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe**

The Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) is a regional organization that aims to promote greater cooperation and unity among its member states. The OSCE has a wide range of activities, including security, economic cooperation, and environmental protection.

**European Free Trade Association**

The European Free Trade Association (EFTA) is a regional organization that aims to promote greater cooperation and unity among its member states. EFTA has a wide range of activities, including trade, investment, and economic cooperation.

**European Broadcasting Union**

The European Broadcasting Union (EBU) is a regional organization that aims to promote greater cooperation and unity among its member states. The EBU has a wide range of activities, including broadcasting, media, and communication.

**European Patent Convention**

The European Patent Convention is an international treaty that aims to promote greater cooperation and unity among its member states. The Convention has a wide range of activities, including intellectual property, patents, and innovation.

**European Communities**

The European Communities, which include the European Economic Community (EEC), the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC), and the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM), are regional organizations that aim to promote greater cooperation and unity among their member states.

**European Union**

The European Union (EU) is a regional organization that aims to promote greater cooperation and unity among its member states. The EU has a wide range of activities, including economic cooperation, trade, investment, and foreign policy.

### Competences

The EU has a wide range of competences, including economic, social, and political. The EU has the power to make laws, regulate trade, and provide for economic cooperation.

### Economic integration

The EU has a high level of economic integration, with a single market, a single currency, and a customs union. The EU also has a high level of economic cooperation, with a single economic policy and a single monetary policy.

### Free trade area

The EU is a free trade area, with no tariffs or quotas on trade between member states.

### Customs union

The EU is a customs union, with a common external tariff and a common customs policy.

### European Single Market

The EU has a single market, with free movement of goods, services, and capital between member states.

### Eurozone

The EU has a Eurozone, with a single currency, the Euro, among participating member states.

### Fiscal union

The EU has a fiscal union, with a common budget and a common taxation policy.

### Aviation

The EU has a high level of cooperation in aviation, with a common aviation policy and a common aviation safety regulation.

### Energy

The EU has a high level of cooperation in energy, with a common energy policy and a common energy security regulation.

### Standardisation

The EU has a high level of standardisation, with a common standardisation policy and a common standardisation regulation.

### Social and political integration

The EU has a high level of social and political integration, with a common citizenship policy and a common social policy.

### Education

The EU has a common education policy, with a common framework for education and a common framework for vocational training.

### Research

The EU has a common research policy, with a common framework for research and innovation and a common framework for science and technology.

### Health

The EU has a common health policy, with a common framework for health and a common framework for public health.

### Charter of Fundamental Rights

The EU has a common charter of fundamental rights, with a common framework for human rights and a common framework for democracy.

### Right to vote

The EU has a common right to vote, with a common framework for electoral rights and a common framework for the right to vote.

### Schengen Area

The EU has a common Schengen Area, with a common framework for border control and a common framework for visa policy.

### Visa policy in EU

The EU has a common visa policy, with a common framework for visa requirements and a common framework for visa procedures.

### Defence

The EU has a high level of cooperation in defence, with a common defence policy and a common defence regulation.

### Space

The EU has a high level of cooperation in space, with a common space policy and a common space regulation.

### Membership in European Union agreements

The EU has a wide range of membership agreements, including the European Economic Area (EEA) agreement, the Schengen Agreement, and the Eurozone agreement.

**Future of European integration**

The future of European integration is uncertain, with many challenges and opportunities on the horizon.

### European Security Treaty

The European Security Treaty is a proposed treaty that aims to create a common security and defense policy among EU member states.

### Common space from Lisbon to Vladivostok

The common space from Lisbon to Vladivostok is a proposed concept that aims to create a common economic and security space from the Atlantic to the Pacific.

### Concept of a single legal space for the CIS and Europe

The concept of a single legal space for the CIS and Europe is a proposed concept that aims to create a common legal framework for the countries of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) and Europe.

**Beyond Europe**

European integration extends beyond Europe, with many countries and regions participating in various regional organizations and agreements.

### Euro-Mediterranean Partnership

The Euro-Mediterranean Partnership is a regional organization that aims to promote greater cooperation and unity among its member states.

### Ties with partners

The Euro-Mediterranean Partnership has ties with many countries and regions, including the Mediterranean region, the Middle East, and North Africa.

### Commonwealth of Independent States

The Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) is a regional organization that aims to promote greater cooperation and unity among its member states.

### Community for Democracy and Rights of Nations

The Community for Democracy and Rights of Nations is a regional organization that aims to promote greater cooperation and unity among its member states.

### EU and other regions and countries in the world

The EU has ties with many regions and countries in the world, including the Americas, Africa, and Asia.

### Other organisations in world

The EU has ties with many other organisations in the world, including the United Nations, the G20, and the G7.

### European languages in the world

The EU has a wide range of languages, including English, French, German, Italian, and Spanish, which are widely spoken around the world.

### World integration

The EU is a key player in world integration, with a strong commitment to promoting global cooperation and unity.

**2022–23 NCAA Football Bowl Games**

The 2022–23 NCAA football bowl games were a series of postseason college football games played in the United States to conclude the 2022 NCAA Division I Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS) and Football Championship Subdivision (FCS) seasons. The bowl season began on December 17, 2022, and concluded with the College Football Playoff National Championship Game on January 9, 2023.

**Schedule**

### College Football Playoff and National Championship Game

The College Football Playoff (CFP) is a four-team playoff system for the NCAA Division I Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS). The 2022–23 CFP featured the same four teams that participated in the previous season: Alabama, Cincinnati, Michigan, and Georgia. The semifinal games were played on December 31, 2022, at the Sugar Bowl and the Orange Bowl, with the winners advancing to the College Football Playoff National Championship Game. The national championship game was played on January 9, 2023, at SoFi Stadium in Inglewood, California.

### Non CFP Bowl Games

There were a total of 42 bowl games played in the 2022–23 NCAA football bowl season, with the first game being played on December 17, 2022, and the last game being played on January 2, 2023. The non-CFP bowl games were divided into two categories: Bowl Championship Series (BCS) bowls and non-BCS bowls. The BCS bowls were the Cotton Bowl, the Fiesta Bowl, the Peach Bowl, and the Rose Bowl, while the non-BCS bowls included the other 38 games.

#### Bowl Changes

For the 2022–23 bowl season, several changes were made to the traditional bowl schedule. The most notable change was the addition of the Fenway Bowl, which replaced the Gasparilla Bowl. Additionally, the Sun Bowl was moved to December 30, 2022, to accommodate the schedule of the two semifinal games in the College Football Playoff. The Holiday Bowl was also moved to December 27, 2022, and the Gator Bowl was moved to December 29, 2022.

**Sudanese Civil War (2023–present)**

The Sudanese Civil War is an ongoing conflict in Sudan that began in 2023. The war is a complex and multifaceted conflict that involves various factions, including the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF), the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), the Sudan People's Liberation Movement-North (SPLM-N), and the Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM).

**Background**

### War in Darfur and the formation of the RSF

The conflict in Sudan has its roots in the Second Sudanese Civil War, which began in 1983 and ended in 2005. The war in Darfur, which began in 2003, was a major factor in the formation of the RSF. The RSF was initially formed as a militia group to fight against the Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) in Darfur. However, the RSF later became a powerful force in Sudanese politics, with its leader, Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo (also known as Hemedti), playing a key role in the country's political transition.

### Political transition

In 2019, the Sudanese military, led by General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, ousted President Omar al-Bashir, who had been in power since 1989. The military established a transitional council to govern the country, with General al-Burhan as its head. However, the transition was marked by power struggles and tensions between the military and the civilian leaders. The RSF, which had been a key player in the military's rise to power, became increasingly influential in the country's politics.

2022 United States gubernatorial elections

The 2022 United States gubernatorial elections were held on November 8, 2022, to elect the governors of 36 states, as well as the governors of the District of Columbia, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

Partisan composition

Prior to the 2022 elections, the partisan composition of the 36 governorships up for election was:

*   Republican: 26
*   Democratic: 22
*   Independent: 0

Election predictions

Based on various polls and forecasts, many political analysts predicted a significant shift in the partisan composition of the governorships. Some predicted that Republicans would gain as many as 10-15 seats, while others predicted a more modest gain of 5-7 seats.

Race summary

### States

The 2022 gubernatorial elections in the 36 states up for election were highly competitive, with many close races and several upsets.

article:
The 2022 Indonesia President's Cup was the 25th edition of the Indonesia President's Cup, a national football tournament held in Indonesia. The tournament took place from 30 September to 6 November 2022, with eight professional clubs participating from the Liga 1, Indonesia's top-tier football league.

## Teams

The eight participating teams in the 2022 Indonesia President's Cup were:

* Bali United
* Borneo
* Dewa United
* Madura United
* PSM Makassar
* Persija Jakarta
* Persib Bandung
* Persebaya Surabaya

## Venues

The tournament was held at the following venues:

* Gelora Bandung Lautan Api Stadium, Bandung
* Manahan Stadium, Surakarta
* Maguwoharjo Stadium, Sleman
* Kapten I Wayan Dipta Stadium, Gianyar
* Jalak Harupat Stadium, Sumedang

## Draw

The draw for the 2022 Indonesia President's Cup took place on 26 September 2022 at the Jakarta Convention Center in Jakarta. The eight participating teams were drawn into two groups of four teams each. The draw was conducted by the chairman of the Indonesia Football Federation (PSSI), Mochamad Iriawan.

## Format

The 2022 Indonesia President's Cup followed a single-elimination format, with the eight participating teams competing in a knockout tournament. The tournament consisted of a group stage and a knockout stage. In the group stage, the teams were divided into two groups of four teams each, with each team playing the other teams in their group once. article:
2023 NFL Draft

The 2023 NFL Draft was the 88th annual meeting of National Football League (NFL) franchises to select newly eligible college football players and other eligible players for the 2023 NFL season. The draft was held from April 27 to 29, 2023, at the Caesars Forum in Las Vegas, Nevada.

# Host city and events

The 2023 NFL Draft was hosted in Las Vegas, Nevada, for the second consecutive year. The Caesars Forum, a 550,000-square-foot (51,000 square meters) conference center, was the site of the draft. The event featured five stages, with the first round taking place on the main stage, followed by the second and third rounds on a smaller stage. The fourth and seventh rounds were held on a third stage, while the fifth, sixth, and 10th rounds took place on the fourth stage. The 2023 NFL Draft was broadcast live on ABC, ESPN, the NFL Network, and the NFL app.

# Player selections

The 2023 NFL Draft consisted of seven rounds, with each team selecting one player per round. A total of 259 players were selected in the draft. The first overall pick was C.J. Stroud, a quarterback from Ohio State University, selected by the Houston Texans. The second overall pick was Bryce Young, a quarterback from the University of Alabama, selected by the Carolina Panthers. The third overall pick was Will Levis, a quarterback from the University of Kentucky, selected by the Tennessee Titans.

The top 10 selections of the 2023 NFL Draft were:

1. C.J. Stroud, QB, Ohio State University (Houston Texans)
2. Bryce Young, QB, University of Alabama (Carolina Panthers)
3. Will Levis, QB, University of Kentucky (Tennessee Titans)
4. Jaxon Smith-Njigba, WR, Ohio State University (Philadelphia Eagles)
5. Paris Johnson Jr., OT, Ohio State University (Cincinnati Bengals)
6. Peter Skoronski, OT, Northwestern University (Chicago Bears)
7. Jalen Carter, DT, Georgia University (Philadelphia Eagles)
8. Quentin Johnston, WR, University of TCU (Los Angeles Chargers)
9. Anton Harrison, OT, University of Oklahoma (Seattle Seahawks)
10. O'Cyrus Torrence, OG, University of Florida (Cleveland Browns)

# Notable undrafted players

Several players who were not selected in the 2023 NFL Draft went on to sign with NFL teams as undrafted free agents. Some notable players who signed as undrafted free agents include:

* Deonte Banks, CB, University of Maryland (Baltimore Ravens)
* Bryce Thompson, CB, University of Tennessee (Arizona Cardinals)
* Tyrique Stevenson, CB, University of Miami (Atlanta Falcons)
* Felix Anudike-Uzomah, DE, Kansas State University (Kansas City Chiefs)
* Noah Sewell, LB, University of Oregon (Las Vegas Raiders)

# Trades

There were several trades made during the 2023 NFL Draft. The most notable trade was the swap of picks between the Houston Texans and the Carolina Panthers. The Texans sent their first overall pick (C.J. Stroud) and a 2024 first-round pick to the Panthers in exchange for the Panthers' first overall pick (Bryce Young), a 2024 second-round pick, and a 2025 third-round pick.

Other notable trades included:

* The Philadelphia Eagles traded their 2023 first-round pick (Jaxon Smith-Njigba) to the Houston Texans in exchange for a 2023 first-round pick and a 2024 second-round pick.
* The Cincinnati Bengals traded their 2023 first-round pick (Paris Johnson Jr.) to the Chicago Bears in exchange for a 2023 first-round pick and a 2024 fourth-round pick.
* The Los Angeles Chargers traded their 2023 first-round pick (Quentin Johnston) to the Seattle Seahawks in exchange for a 2023 first-round pick and a 2024 fifth-round pick.

# 2020 Resolution JC-2A selections

The 2023 NFL Draft included several players who were selected under the 2020 Resolution JC-2A. This resolution allowed teams to select players who were not eligible for the normal draft but had completed three years of college or had completed three years in the Canadian Football League. Some notable players selected under the 2020 Resolution JC-2A include:

* Daniel Faalele, OT, University of Minnesota (Baltimore Ravens)
* Jameson Williams, WR, University of Alabama (Detroit Lions)
* Josh Palmer, WR, University of Tennessee (Los Angeles Chargers)

# Supplemental draft

The 2023 NFL Draft also included a supplemental draft. The supplemental draft allowed teams to select players who were not eligible for the normal draft but had completed their college eligibility. Some notable players selected in the supplemental draft include:

* Tank Dell, WR, Houston University (Houston Texans)
* Dallas Turner, DE, University of Alabama (Green Bay Packers)

# Notes

The 2023 NFL Draft was the first draft to feature a new format, with the first round taking place on the main stage, followed by the second and third rounds on a smaller stage. The fourth and seventh rounds were held on a third stage, while the fifth, sixth, and 10th rounds took place on the fourth stage.

**2023 Spain Masters**

The 2023 Spain Masters was a badminton tournament that took place from March 7 to 12, 2023, at the Palau Sant Jordi in Barcelona, Spain. The tournament was part of the BWF World Tour Super 300 series and was the fifth Super 300 tournament of the 2022-2023 season.

**Venue**

The tournament was held at the Palau Sant Jordi, a multi-purpose indoor arena located in Barcelona, Spain. The arena has a seating capacity of over 17,000 and is one of the largest indoor arenas in Europe. The Palau Sant Jordi has hosted numerous international sports events, including the 1992 Summer Olympics and the 2004 European Men's Handball Championship.

**Point distribution**

The point distribution for the 2023 Spain Masters was as follows:

* Men's singles: 500 points for the winner, 390 points for the runner-up, 290 points for the semifinalist, 180 points for the quarterfinalist, and 100 points for the round of 16.
* Women's singles: 500 points for the winner, 390 points for the runner-up, 290 points for the semifinalist, 180 points for the quarterfinalist, and 100 points for the round of 16.
* Men's doubles: 600 points for the winner, 450 points for the runner-up, 330 points for the semifinalist, 200 points for the quarterfinalist, and 100 points for the round of 16.
* Women's doubles: 600 points for the winner, 450 points for the runner-up, 330 points for the semifinalist, 200 points for the quarterfinalist, and 100 points for the round of 16.
* Mixed doubles: 640 points for the winner, 480 points for the runner-up, 360 points for the semifinalist, 220 points for the quarterfinalist, and 100 points for the round of 16.

**Prize money**

The total prize money for the 2023 Spain Masters was $400,000. The prize money distribution was as follows:

* Men's singles: $14,000 for the winner, $7,000 for the runner-up, $3,500 for the semifinalist, $2,000 for the quarterfinalist, and $1,000 for the round of 16.
* Women's singles: $14,000 for the winner, $7,000 for the runner-up, $3,500 for the semifinalist, $2,000 for the quarterfinalist, and $1,000 for the round of 16.
* Men's doubles: $16,000 for the winner, $8,000 for the runner-up, $4,000 for the semifinalist, $2,500 for the quarterfinalist, and $1,250 for the round of 16.
* Women's doubles: $16,000 for the winner, $8,000 for the runner-up, $4,000 for the semifinalist, $2,500 for the quarterfinalist, and $1,250 for the round of 16.
* Mixed doubles: $17,000 for the winner, $9,000 for the runner-up, $4,500 for the semifinalist, $2,750 for the quarterfinalist, and $1,375 for the round of 16.

**Men's singles**

#### Seeds

The seeds for the men's singles event were as follows:

1. 1. Anders Antonsen (Denmark)
2. 2. Lee Zii Jia (Malaysia)
3. 3. Lakshya Sen (India)

article:
Impeachment of Samuel Chase

The impeachment of Samuel Chase was a significant event in United States history, taking place in 1804. Chase, a federal judge and a prominent figure in the Federalist Party, was accused of misconduct in office, specifically of using his position to influence the outcome of trials.

Background

Samuel Chase was born in 1741 in Somerset County, Maryland. He studied law and was admitted to the bar in 1761. Chase served as a delegate to the Continental Congress during the American Revolution and later became a federal judge in 1796. He was a vocal advocate for the Federalist Party and was known for his strong opinions on the role of the judiciary.

Impeachment in the House of Representatives

### Vote to launch impeachment inquiry

In December 1803, the House of Representatives voted to launch an impeachment inquiry against Samuel Chase. The motion was introduced by Representative Joseph B. Varnum of Massachusetts, who argued that Chase had used his position to influence the outcome of trials in favor of the Federalist Party. The vote was 73-32 in favor of launching the inquiry.

### Early inquiry developments

The impeachment inquiry began in January 1804, with the House Judiciary Committee conducting hearings to gather evidence against Chase. The committee heard testimony from several witnesses, including judges, lawyers, and politicians. The inquiry focused on Chase's behavior in several high-profile trials, including the case of Thomas Lloyd, a Federalist Party member who was accused of treason.

### Adoption of impeachment resolution

In February 1804, the House Judiciary Committee presented its report to the full House, recommending that impeachment proceedings be brought against Chase. The report outlined several charges against Chase, including:

* High crimes and misdemeanors
* Misconduct in office
* Abuse of power

The House voted to adopt the report and move forward with impeachment proceedings.

### Subsequent months of inquiry

Over the next several months, the House continued to gather evidence and hear testimony against Chase. The inquiry was marked by intense partisan debate, with many Federalist Party members defending Chase and arguing that the proceedings were politically motivated.

### Adoption of articles of impeachment

In March 1804, the House voted to adopt seven articles of impeachment against Chase. Each article outlined a specific charge against Chase, including:

### Article I

* High crimes and misdemeanors
* Misconduct in office
* Abuse of power

Chase was accused of using his position to influence the outcome of trials in favor of the Federalist Party.

### Article II

* Misconduct in office
